citations.narrative:
Inside the 2nd outdoor chain link enclosure from the west a smaller gauge wire panel was placed over the chain link
separating the enclosures at the level of the enclosed Corgi dog. This smaller gauge wire was torn and bent creating
multiple sharp points into the enclosure at the bottom part of the panel putting the damaged area at approximately the
level of the Corgi's head. Sharp points create a potential hazard for injury.
In the shelter building, the floors of the inside part are made of plastic grating. Two of the enclosures have damaged floors
that could result in entrapment or injury. One enclosure containing a single female Corgi has a large hole (approximately
2" x 6") by the dog door. The other floor (enclosing 2 dogs) has several large breaks in the center of the floor supported
by a cement block placed under the floor. The licensee must maintain flooring and other surfaces to prevent injury or
entrapment of the enclosed dogs.
To be corrected by: 20 January 2026
The damaged wire was repaired at the time of inspection.

In an outdoor enclosure with 1 adult Poodle dog, the bottom of a black water receptacle was covered with a layer of green
algae-like material. This algae-like material may be harmful to the dog and indicates that the receptacle has not been kept
clean and sanitized. The licensee must clean and sanitize and maintain the water receptacles for the health and well
being of the dogs.
Corrected during the inspection

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
Inside the entry where the unopened bags of dog food are stacked, there was a large amount of rodent feces on the floor
and pallet around the food. There were 3 plastic carriers stacked next to the dog food which also had rodent feces along
the edges and inside the carriers. A "sticky trap" and small bag of rodent bait were on the floor between the wall and pallet
but the large amount of rodent feces indicate that the current pest control plan is ineffective. Rodents carry diseases that
can affect the dogs and contaminate the food. The licensee must establish an effective program for the control of insects,
external parasites affecting dogs, and animals that are pests, and maintained so as to promote the health and well-being
of the animals and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas.
To be corrected by: 16 January 2026

The medical records of 2 dogs were incomplete. Information on medication given, dose, route and times given were not
provided. This information is required as part of a complete medical record. Licensee must record the date and a
description of the problem, examination findings, test results, plan for treatment and care, and treatment procedures
performed.
To be corrected by: 14 January 2026
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Lindsay Livingston, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.1(a) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Inside the 2nd outdoor chain link enclosure from the west a smaller gauge wire panel was placed over the chain link 
separating the enclosures at the level of the enclosed Corgi dog. This smaller gauge wire was torn and bent creating 
multiple sharp points into the enclosure at the bottom part of the panel putting the damaged area at approximately the 
level of the Corgi's head. Sharp points create a potential hazard for injury.  
 
In the shelter building, the floors of the inside part are made of plastic grating. Two of the enclosures have damaged floors 
that could result in entrapment or injury. One enclosure containing a single female Corgi has a large hole (approximately 
2" x 6") by the dog door. The other floor (enclosing 2 dogs) has several large breaks in the center of the floor supported 
by a cement block placed under the floor. The licensee must maintain flooring and other surfaces to prevent injury or 
entrapment of the enclosed dogs.  
 
To be corrected by: 20 January 2026 
The damaged wire was repaired at the time of inspection. 
3.10(c) 
   
Watering 
In an outdoor enclosure with 1 adult Poodle dog, the bottom of a black water receptacle was covered with a layer of green 
algae-like material. This algae-like material may be harmful to the dog and indicates that the receptacle has not been kept 
clean and sanitized. The licensee must clean and sanitize and maintain the water receptacles for the health and well 
being of the dogs.  
 
Corrected during the inspection 
3.11(d) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
Inside the entry where the unopened bags of dog food are stacked, there was a large amount of rodent feces on the floor 
and pallet around the food. There were 3 plastic carriers stacked next to the dog food which also had rodent feces along 
the edges and inside the carriers. A "sticky trap" and small bag of rodent bait were on the floor between the wall and pallet

but the large amount of rodent feces indicate that the current pest control plan is ineffective. Rodents carry diseases that 
can affect the dogs and contaminate the food. The licensee must establish an effective program for the control of insects, 
external parasites affecting dogs, and animals that are pests, and maintained so as to promote the health and well-being 
of the animals and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas. 
 
To be corrected by: 16 January 2026 
3.13(b)(2) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The medical records of 2 dogs were incomplete. Information on medication given, dose, route and times given were not 
provided. This information is required as part of a complete medical record. Licensee must record the date and a 
description of the problem, examination findings, test results, plan for treatment and care, and treatment procedures 
performed. 
 
To be corrected by: 14 January 2026 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Lindsay Livingston, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
